unit.title: Reading for Meaning II: Longer Texts & Critical Reading
unit.overview: Learners tackle slightly longer texts (multi-paragraph non-fiction and informational articles) and practise strategies for skimming, scanning, recognising text features, distinguishing fact from opinion, spotting bias, and evaluating sources. Lessons are short, interactive, and NaCCA-aligned with Ghanaian contexts and Christian moral framing (truthfulness, diligence, stewardship).
competencies: Use skimming and scanning to locate main ideas, headings, and key facts.
Interpret common non-fiction text features (headings, subheadings, captions, charts, diagrams).
Differentiate facts from opinions and recognise bias or persuasive techniques.
Evaluate credibility of a short passage or source using simple criteria (author, date, purpose).
Synthesize information across two short texts into a clear summary or comparison.
values_morals: Seek truth and fairness when reading and sharing information.
Stewardship: use information to improve school and community life.

lessons.title: Text Features: Headings, Captions, & Diagrams
objectives: Identify and explain how headings, subheadings, captions, and charts support understanding.
Use features to predict and verify main ideas.

vocabulary.definition: A short explanation below an image or chart.
A labelled drawing that explains how something works.
A smaller title under a heading that introduces a section.

lessons.moral_link: Orderly presentation helps others learn well.

content_blocks.body: Scan headings first. Read captions. Check diagrams for steps or parts. Then read paragraphs for details.

classify.prompt: Match each feature to its function.

quick_check.q: Which feature best explains a process at a glance?

lessons.title: Skimming & Scanning Strategies
objectives: Skim for main idea (titles, first sentences, key words).
Scan for specific facts (dates, names, numbers).

vocabulary.definition: Read quickly to understand the general idea.
Look quickly for a specific piece of information.

lessons.moral_link: Use time wisely: choose the right reading strategy for the task.

content_blocks.body: Skim: title → headings → first sentences → keywords. Scan: move your eyes down the page for numbers, dates, names.

ai_task.prompt: Given a multi‑paragraph article, first write one sentence with the main idea (skim). Then list three facts with numbers or names (scan).

lessons.title: Fact vs Opinion and Spotting Bias
objectives: Identify simple bias or persuasive language in short excerpts.

vocabulary.definition: A statement that can be proved true or false.
A personal belief or feeling that cannot be proved.
Favouring one side unfairly; slanted presentation.

lessons.moral_link: Be fair. Share information truthfully without twisting it.

content_blocks.body: Fact clues: numbers, dates, measurable claims. Opinion clues: 'best', 'worst', 'I think', value-laden adjectives.

content_blocks.caption: From fact to opinion—spot the language.

classify.prompt: Label each as Fact (F) or Opinion (O).

items.text: The school clean‑up collected 25 bags of rubbish.
items.label: F

items.text: Clean schools are the best schools in the world.
items.label: O

error_hunt.text: Everyone knows the new library is the most useless building ever! It’s always empty.
tasks: Identify bias words and rewrite fairly.
error_hunt.solution_hint: Replace extreme language; add factual evidence.

lessons.title: Evaluate Sources: Who? When? Why?
objectives: Use simple criteria for credibility: author/organisation, date, purpose/audience.
Decide if a text is suitable for school research.

vocabulary.definition: Reason the text was made: inform, persuade, entertain, sell.

lessons.moral_link: Honour truth: choose reliable sources and cite honestly.

content_blocks.body: Check: Who wrote it? When was it published? Why was it written? Is the language balanced or extreme?

source_rating.prompt: Rate each 'source card' as Strong / OK / Weak with a short reason.

lessons.title: Synthesis Task: Compare Two Texts
objectives: Combine key ideas from two short texts into a brief summary or comparison.
Use linking words (however, therefore, meanwhile) to show relationships.

vocabulary.definition: Combine ideas to form a connected understanding.
Words that connect ideas (e.g., however, therefore, meanwhile).

lessons.moral_link: Use information to plan helpful actions for school and community.

content_blocks.title: Text A: School Water Conservation
content_blocks.body:
Our school’s water bill rose last term. The science club studied common causes: leaking taps, long washing
times, and broken gutters during rainstorms. The club measured flow rates and found three taps leaking
constantly. They proposed simple fixes: report leaks, install tap aerators, and collect rainwater in drums for
cleaning.

content_blocks.title: Text B: Clean Water & Health
content_blocks.body:
Clean water prevents disease and saves time. When schools provide hand‑washing stations, attendance improves.
A local clinic’s data show fewer stomach illnesses after hand‑washing education. Community groups support
schools with low-cost tanks and soap drives.

ai_task.prompt: Write a 4–5 sentence comparison: What does each text focus on, and how do their ideas fit together for a school plan? Use two linking words.

quiz_mcq.q: Which feature most likely labels parts of a process?

options: The clean‑up collected 25 bags of rubbish.
Clean schools are the best in the universe.

quiz_mcq.q: A source is most credible when:
options: It is recent, from a known organisation, and uses balanced language.
It is anonymous and uses extreme language.
It is very old and has no author.
It is a rumour shared by a friend.
Combining ideas into a connected whole

quiz_mcq.q: An example of bias language is:

options: Focus on the main idea and key points

writing_prompt.prompt: Write a 4–6 sentence summary that synthesises Text A and Text B into a simple plan for your school’s water and health practices. Use at least two text features (e.g., a heading and a caption) in your final layout.

criteria.name: Main Ideas & Accuracy
criteria.descriptor: Captures key ideas from both texts correctly.

criteria.name: Connections & Linking Words
criteria.descriptor: Shows how ideas relate; uses appropriate connectors.

criteria.name: Clarity & Mechanics (UK)
criteria.descriptor: Clear sentences; correct spelling and punctuation.
